title: Have you ever self-published a book on Amazon that did really well? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Many years ago, I self-published some erotic novels on Amazon under the pen name William Vitelli that did extremely well: Elicitation, Evocation, and The Webcam Chronicles. I was, for a time, making about $2,000 a month from sales. Then the so called “pornapocalypse” happened. Bowing to pressure from religious groups, Amazon began limiting the way self-published erotica appears in searches. In some cases, even if you search for the exact title and author of a self-published erotic novel, you’ll find no results; you have to know the book’s ASIN to find it. Overnight, my income from self-published erotica dropped from $2,000 a month to $400 a month, then to $200 a month, and it’s currently holding steady at $25-$40 a month. I’m actually making slightly more from Smashwords with self-published erotica these days; averaging about $38-$55 a month. Last month was pretty good. Here’s my income from self-published erotica on Amazon last month:  Pretty far call from $2k+/month, eh?

upvoters.user_id: Jack Davies（デイビースジャック）

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A on this one. Yes. These three. In 2018.  Releasing a book is a funny thing, since you never know how well it’s going to do. So when this book, which I wasn’t even sure anyone would like, made it to #1 in all it’s sub-categories, and #132 in the paid Kindle store, I was totally blown away.  Everyone hated the end of of the first book and demanded a sequel, and it did even better, getting to #97 in the paid Kindle store.  The third in the now trilogy reached #218 in the paid Kindle store. All three books were released around 6 weeks apart. So the momentum was maintained for the whole trilogy. Originally planned as a stand alone, by the end of the trilogy I’d merged them into my existing universe as series 3, setting up a lot of possibilities for series 4. It’s an interesting observation that in totally sucking at writing a stand alone book, it was my second best performing book to date. The sequel was the best.

Yes - well, I thought it did well. When I first started writing fiction almost six years ago, my genre had very little competition and readers were keen to try new authors. I made $10,000 USD with my first book in the first month and haven’t looked back. However, markets change, the rules on erotica (mine were on the erotica/romance divide), and readers’ tastes change. I still make good money every month I put out a new release, but nowhere near what I used to. In the current market, I still make $10,000 a month, but that includes translated copies and a huge back list sales as well. But I do all right, and I love my stories, so I am not likely to give up writing anytime soon. Thank you for the A2A.

Really well? Like, enough to quit my day job? Nope. However, I have had some moderate success with a couple of non-fiction books that I have self-published on Amazon, as you can see from my most current royalties report:  Only about $100 or so last month, which is about average. Nothing special, but certainly better than nothing. One of the books is a rather slim (although fully illustrated) tome explaining the basics of pocket watch collecting for people just getting started. I’ve had a website devoted to the subject for many years and for awhile I was self printing the book and selling it directly from my website. I eventually moved the entire operation to Cafepress, and when they stopped printing books I moved it to Amazon. The other book is a collection of essays I have written on the topic of religion and atheism, drawn primarily from answers and posts I have written here on Quora. As with my pocket watch book, it attracts a very niche audience, so I never expected to make tons of money.

Yes. In February 2019, I self-published a book on Amazon called What did Tashi do? I don’t know what the question means by “really well”, but here are the positive changes that happened in my life after publishing the book- Over a span of 8 months, the book has sold 3000+ copies worldwide and has garnered more than 100 positive reviews on Goodreads.I started getting invited to talks on book writing and publishing in several private and government institutions all over the country. Because the sales were going so good on Amazon, a Canada-based publishing house, Ukiyoto noticed my book and asked for an exclusive traditional publishing deal for distribution of paperbacks all over the world. Thus, five months after the eBook was released, What did Tashi do? was available as a paperback. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts - an ancillary body of Ministry of Culture, Government of India invited me to read a few of my poems as part of their “Voices of North East India” series - an initiative to recognise talented writers from this part of the country. This was the first time in my life I was invited to an event on such a scale, and also the first time I was paid for performing poetry in front of a live audience. People from all over the world started downloading the eBook of What did Tashi do? and writing heartfelt reviews for it. In fact, the book has over 20 positive reviews on the US and UK versions of Amazon.During my author workshops and book-talk events, people started to walk up to me once the event was done and request me to sign their copies. For a girl who has grown up with the dream of being a published writer, this fan-moment feels surreal still. The best and perhaps the most significant thing that has happened in my life after the book was out is the steady stream of money I get from sales. As of now, it isn’t enough to eke out a living, but, depending on the number of sales, I earn something between $15 to $35 in a month.For a newbie writer, I think this self-published book could be considered to have done “really well”. Of course, there’s a long way to go before I can say my dream of being a full-time, well-known writer has been achieved, but till then, one is allowed to be happy in those little achievements they pick up along the way, right?  Join my email list to keep in touch

So far. I published “Reviving the Art of Innovation- using your sense to make a dollar” a couple of months ago on amazon to help kids 8–80 (I’m 15) to be able to accomplish what I have in business. It moves up and down, But made it to #51 on the top #100 in the category. It has been selling equally well in both the US and Canada, and has got me spots on national shows to promote the book. Its been a lot of fun!

Not yet, but I’m working on it. My latest book, A Programmer’s Guide to Computer Science, was released nearly three months ago. If the current sales numbers hold it’ll make around $10k this year, front-loaded into the first month of release.  My hope is that as more reviews come in and I publish more volumes in the series, they’ll continue to sell and provide a steady income. The single book that makes a ton of money is a rarity. Most authors who make a good living from their writing do so by consistently turning out good books.

Thanks for the A2A. If you mean “Have I earned a lot of money on it?” then no. Actually, my only book (so far) has earned nothing since release, but I didn’t expect it to either. I’m actually writing for telling the story, rather than earning money, and I’ve gained some readers in the process.
Yes. Many. Thank you for asking.
